page.title: 03Doetor Brook
page.content: Dartmoor is noted for its rivers and brooks.{Doetor Brook } is a good example of the smaller rivers and well repays a visit. It joins the Lydd just below {High Down}and can be followed in an easterly direction to its source at {Dicks Well, }where extensive tinners spoil heaps can be seen. { }Climbing up the brook there is constant reminders of the industrial past of Dartmoor. The remains of the{Wheal Mary Emma}can be seen. Just above a picturesque waterfall another leat joins the brook, and in its turn eventually joins with the{Reddiford {Leat.}This leat then drains into the {Wheal Jewel Leat,}and the water provides power that is fed into the {National Grid.}Consequently the leats, built by hand by the Dartmoor Tinners provide electricity for us today.
